Description: Fragmentary jar with pointed base: the wreck of a fine piece. The shape, directly copied from pottery wine jars, was popular late in the Eighteenth Dynasty. The opaque light turquoise-blue field is decorated in a flowing festoon pattern in white and yellow bordered at its upper level with a white and a yellow thread. Both the shoulder and the rim are encircled with a prefabricated twisted cord in yellow and black (?). The original surface was probably glossy. On the neck a chevron pattern in opaque white and yellow. The sole remaining handle is in opaque black glass overlaid with threads of opaque white and yellow. The body is very incompletely preserved.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Illahun, Kahun and Gurob’ 1889-1890 (London 1891), p.17, pl. XVII, 37. The vessel was found in a deposit under a house which had been fired; B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 72 (under no. 90-11-9, 3), pl. XVI, 1.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1891 / Illahun, Kahun and Gurob (p. 17, pl. XVII)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
